column2: Drude, Sebastian. 2008. Nasal harmony in Awetí and the Mawetí-Guarani family (Tupí). (Ed.) Francesc Queixalós & Leo Wetzels. Amerindia, 32. 239–276. Drude, Sebastian. 2009. Nasal harmony in Awetí: a declarative account. ReVEL, 3. 1-26. Drude, Sebastian. 2020. A fonología do Awetí. Revista Brasileira de Línguas Indígenas (RBLI), 3(2). 185-205

{{p, p}, {t, t}, {k, k}, {ts, ts}, {m, m}, {n, n}, {ŋ, ŋ}, {ɾ, ɾ}, {j, j}, {w, w}, {l, l}, {ʐ, ʐ}, {ɣ, ɣ}, {h, h}, {ʔ, ʔ}, {i, i}, {ɨ, ɨ}, {ɛ, ɛ}, {a, a}, {ɔ, ɔ}, {u, u}, {ĩ, ĩ}, {ɨ̃, ɨ̃}, {ɛ̃, ɛ̃}, {ã, ã}, {ɔ̃, ɔ̃}, {ũ, ũ}, {u, {u, o}, @, o-lowering}, {i, {i̯, j}, $*_, {i̯-vowel shortening, j-gliding}}, {u, {u̯, w}, $*_, {u̯-vowel shortening, w-gliding}}, {ɛ, j, $*_, gliding}, {t, tʃ, V_i, palatalization}, {t, ntʃ, Ṽ_i, LN:TtoNT}, {//P//, m, Ṽ_, LN:TTtoN}, {//T//, n, Ṽ_, LN:TTtoN}, {//K//, ŋ, Ṽ_, LN:TTtoN}, {p, {mp, mb}, Ṽ_, {mp-LN:TtoNT, mb-LN:TtoNT}}, {t, {nt, nd}, Ṽ_, {nt-LN:TtoNT, nd-LN:TtoNT}}, {k, {ŋk, ŋɡ}, Ṽ_, {ŋk-LN:TtoNT, ŋɡ-LN:TtoNT}}, {ts, {nts, nds, ndz}, Ṽ_, {nts-LN:TtoNT, nds-LN:TtoNT, ndz-LN:TtoNT}}, {a, ã, &, LDNH}, {e, ɛ̃, &, LDNH}, {i, ĩ, &, LDNH}, {ɨ, ɨ̃, &, LDNH}, {o, ɔ̃, &, LDNH} {u, ũ, &, LDNH}, {w, w̃, {Ṽ_, _Ṽ}, LN:wj}, {j, {j̃, ɲ}, {Ṽ_, _Ṽ}, {j̃-LN:wj, ɲ-LN:wj}}, {l, l̃, &, LDNH}, {ɾ, ɾ̃, &, LDNH}, {ʐ, ʐ̃, &, LDNH}, {a, a, &, LDOH:V}, {e, ɛ, &, LDOH:V}, {i, i, &, LDOH:V}, {ɨ, ɨ, &, LDOH:V}, {o, ɔ, &, LDOH:V} {u, u, &, LDOH:V}, {//P//, p̚, {V_{%, #}, _T}, unreleasing}, {//T//, t̚, {V_{%, #}, _T}, unreleasing}, {//K//, k̚, {V_{%, #}, _T}, unreleasing}, {//P//, {β, w, u̯}, _(#){V, w, j, ʔ}, {β-lenition, w-lenition, u̯-lenition}}, {//T//, ɾ, _(#){V, w, j, ʔ}, lenition}, {//K//, ɣ, _(#){V, w, j, ʔ}, lenition}, {m, ~, /CV//TT//=mɛ/, CVN=ɛ, LN:me}, {//P//, m, /CV//P//=mɛ/, CVm=ɛ, LN:me}, {//T//, n, /CV//T//=mɛ/, CVn=ɛ, LN:me}, {//K//, ŋ, /CV//K//=mɛ/, CVŋ=ɛ, LN:me}, {j, ɲ, /CVj=mɛ/, CVɲ=ɛ̃, LN:me}}

Page numbers are given for all 3 articles by the author. The notation //X// refers to archiphonemes. //TT// refers to the natural class of archiphonemes //P//, //T//, and //K//, which are underspecified voiceless obstruents restricted to root final position. //V// represents Drude's class of 'neutral vowels', which he describes as archiphonemes which are neither nasal nor oral (2009:13). Drude later assumes that they are not archiphonemes (2009:6, note 7), seemingly contradicting previous claims; we have assumed they are archiphonemes and notated them as such for the purpose of simplicity and consistency with other processes. 'Neutral' vowels are distributionally restricted to prefixes and non-final stem vowels; he notates them as underlined vowels e.g. V, we notate them as //V// for consistency. He goes in depth on the process whereby root-final stop consonants (the archiphonemes) nasalize following root-final nasal vowels, but also mentions that glides undergo the same process (2008:250).  The data point /A-tE-kɨ̃j/ → [ãntɛ̃ŋkɨ̃ɲ] 'I hurt/kill myself' seems to suggest that that the leftward LDNH proposed might actually be bidirectional (2008:244, ex: 6b). Drude notes the following regarding nasalization in vowels in Awetí: "In fact, nasality in Awetí may be rather weak, on nasalized as well as intrinsically nasal vowels, and may even disappear at all under circumstances the details of which have still to be identified (main factors seem to be velocity and carefulness of speech" (2008:245, footnote 7).  Neutral vowels, sonorants, and /ʐ/ are phonotactically constrained against occurring in the final rhyme of the root, but may occur elsewhere. The final consonant must be an archiphoneme stop or /j/, and the final vowel must be phonologically oral or nasal.   Free variation between [u] and [o] is restricted to certain lexical items and noted by the author as "Em Awetí, no entanto, os falantes variam, nestas palavras específicas, quanto ao status fonológico, e não foi-nos possível identificar quaisquer regras que determinassem se um item lexical apresenta ou não esta variação, e quais falantes preferem qual variante (em que circunstâncias). Registramos, portanto, um caso de variação ‘livre’, restrita a alguns itens lexicais" (2020:186). Non-syllabic vowels are denoted with the following diacritic [i̯]. Drude notes the following regarding the phonological status of [ɣ]: "De fato, [ɣ] é incluída (marginalmente, em parêntesis) na tabela fonológica por estar começando a desenvolver-se em um fonema, devido à lexicalização." (2020:189).  A morphophonological alternation documented is that the suffix -mɛ nasalizes the final consonant of the preceding morpheme, and, in case that final consonant is /j/, also nasalize the vowel of /ɛ/ to [ɛ̃]. The /m/ then deletes (2020:20).

{{p, p}, {t, t}, {k, k}, {ts, ts}, {m, m}, {n, n}, {ŋ, ŋ}, {ɾ, ɾ}, {j, j}, {w, w}, {l, l}, {ʐ, ʐ}, {ɣ, ɣ}, {h, h}, {ʔ, ʔ}, {i, i}, {ɨ, ɨ}, {ɛ, ɛ}, {a, a}, {ɔ, ɔ}, {u, u}, {ĩ, ĩ}, {ɨ̃, ɨ̃}, {ɛ̃, ɛ̃}, {ã, ã}, {ɔ̃, ɔ̃}, {ũ, ũ}, {u, {u, o}, @, o-lowering}, {i, {i̯, j}, $*_, {i̯-vowel shortening, j-gliding}}, {u, {u̯, w}, $*_, {u̯-vowel shortening, w-gliding}}, {ɛ, j, $*_, gliding}, {t, tʃ, V_i, palatalization}, {t, ntʃ, Ṽ_i, LN:TtoNT}, {//P//, m, Ṽ_, LN:TTtoN}, {//T//, n, Ṽ_, LN:TTtoN}, {//K//, ŋ, Ṽ_, LN:TTtoN}, {p, {mp, mb}, Ṽ_, LN:TtoNT}, {t, {nt, nd}, Ṽ_, LN:TtoNT}, {k, {ŋk, ŋɡ}, Ṽ_, LN:TtoNT}, {ts, {nts, nds, ndz}, Ṽ_, LN:TtoNT}, {a, ã, &, LDNH}, {e, ɛ̃, &, LDNH}, {i, ĩ, &, LDNH}, {ɨ, ɨ̃, &, LDNH}, {o, ɔ̃, &, LDNH}, {u, ũ, &, LDNH}, {w, w̃, {Ṽ_, _Ṽ}, LN:wj}, {j, {j̃, ɲ}, {Ṽ_, _Ṽ}, LN:wj}, {l, l̃, &, LDNH}, {ɾ, ɾ̃, &, LDNH}, {ʐ, ʐ̃, &, LDNH}, {a, a, &, LDOH:V}, {e, ɛ, &, LDOH:V}, {i, i, &, LDOH:V}, {ɨ, ɨ, &, LDOH:V}, {o, ɔ, &, LDOH:V}, {u, u, &, LDOH:V}, {//P//, p̚, {V_{%, #}, _T}, unreleasing}, {//T//, t̚, {V_{%, #}, _T}, unreleasing}, {//K//, k̚, {V_{%, #}, _T}, unreleasing}, {//P//, {β, w, u̯}, _(#){V, w, j, ʔ}, {β-lenition, β-spirantization, w-lenition, u̯-lenition}}, {//T//, ɾ, _(#){V, w, j, ʔ}, {lenition, spirantization}}, {//K//, ɣ, _(#){V, w, j, ʔ}, {lenition, spirantization}}}
/p, t, k, ts/ prenasalize to [mp ~ mb], [nt ~ nd], [ŋk ~ [ŋɡ] and [nts ~ nds ~ ndz], respectively, after a nasal vowel
Nasality spreads from a root or prefix nasal vowel/consonant leftwards nasalizing 'neutral' vowels and sonorants.
Root-final //P// //T// //K// archiphonemes become nasal consonants [m n ŋ], respectively, after nasal root vowels.
Vowels left of an underlyingly oral stem vowel, analyzed as 'neutral' vowels that are neither oral nor nasal, become oral through harmony.
Nasalization of /w, j/ before or after a nasal vowel
Monserrat, Ruth M.F. 1977. A nasalização em Awetí. Conference Handout:29ª Reunião Anual da Sociedade Brasileira para o Progreso da Ciência (SBPC).

Monserrat proposes underlying nasal consonants (N) and contrastive nasal vowels (Ṽ) for Awetí and posits 3 phonological processes: (1) leftward LDNH, nasalization of oral V and glides {w, j} which can be triggered either by the right nasal consonant or nasal vowel in a root, the prefixes {mõ-, CAUS}, {emĩ-, PATIENT}, or the attenuative suffix {-ĩ} (p. 43 - 44). Voiceless obstruents are transparent in this process; (2) rightward LN, glides are nasalized following a nasal vowel. Based on Monserrat's transcriptions, /j/ can either nasalize to [j̃] or [ɲ], however the author does not provide a clear explanation for the surfacing of either allophone (p. 46-48); (3) bidirectional LN, the nasal portion /m/ of the emphatic suffix {-me} triggers place assimilation and nasalization of the preceding root-final consonant and nasalization of the follow [ɛ] vowel in the {-me} suffix. Following this nasalization process, the {m} in the suffix deletes (p. 48-49).

Data points /maniʔok/ --> [mãnĩʔok] 'mandioc' and /otekɨ̃y/ -->[õdẽɡɨ̃ỹ] 'killed.himself' seem to suggest that leftward LDNH rule is actually bidirectional (p.43-44); Monserrat considers leftward LDNH and rightward LN of {w, j} separate processes. It seems that both could be subsumed under a bidirectional LDNH process.

{mõ, prefix, mõ, mõ, CAUS}, {emĩ, prefix, emĩ, emĩ, PATIENT}, {ĩ.ATTEN, suffix, ĩ, ĩ, ATTENUATIVE}, {mɛ, suffix, mɛ, mɛ, EMP}
LDNH triggered by right-most nasal V or N of root; T are transparent
LDNH triggered by prefixes {mõ, emĩ} or suffix {ĩ.ATTEN}; T are transparent
Nasalization of glides {w, j} after a nasal V
Nasal portion of {-me} suffix nasalizes root-final oral consonant of preceding root and following [ɛ] in suffix, then deletes

Sabino, Wary Kamaiurá. 2016. Awetýza tiʔíngatú: construindo uma gramática da língua Awetý, com contribuições para o conhecimento do seu desenvolvimento histórico. Universidade de Brasília:PhD Dissertation.

Sabino cites Monserrat's (1972/2002) analysis; given that we were unable to access the original source, this citation is coded in its place. Citing Monserrat, Sabino posits underlying nasal consonants (N) and contrastive nasal vowels (Ṽ) for Awetí, along with 3 phonological processes: (1) rightward LN, pre-nasalization of /p, t, k/ to [mp, nt, ŋk]~[mb, nd, ŋɡ] after a nasal vowel; (2) bidirectional LN, nasalization of /j/ to [ɲ] either preceding or following a nasal vowel; (3) leftward LN, nasalization of oral vowels preceding a nasal consonant.

<c> is considered to be [ts] and <ž> for [ʐ]. Based on Monserrat's transcriptions in this citation and later papers by the author, <e> and <ẽ> are considered to be [ɛ] and [ɛ̃], respectively, while <o> and <õ> correspond to [ɔ] and [ɔ̃]. Non-syllabic vowels are marked with the following diacritic [u̯]. Sabino cites the following from Monserrat regarding nasalization of vowels: "na fala rápida, não só se nasalizam as vogais átonas antecedentes à sílaba tônica, mas também se desnasaliza, ao mesmo tempo, a vogal nasal desta última" (p. 45).

{{p, p}, {t, t}, {ts, ts}, {k, k}, {ʔ, ʔ}, {m, m}, {n, n}, {ŋ, ŋ}, {ʐ, ʐ}, {ɾ, ɾ}, {w, w}, {j, j}, {l, l}, {i, i}, {ɨ, ɨ}, {ɛ, ɛ}, {a, a}, {ɔ, ɔ}, {u, u}, {ĩ, ĩ}, {ɨ̃, ɨ̃}, {ɛ̃, ɛ̃}, {ã, ã}, {ɔ̃, ɔ̃}, {ũ, ũ}, {p, p̚, _{%, C}, unreleasing}, {p, β, _V, {lenition, spirantization}}, {t, t̚, _%, unreleasing}, {t, tʲ, _i, palatalization}, {k, k̚, _%, unreleasing}, {k, ɣ, _{V, w}, {lenition, spirantization}}, {w, β, _{e, u}, fortition}, {w, u̯, {_$V, {k, p, ŋ}_}, semivocalization}, {j, i̯, {_$V, {k, p}_}, semivocalization}, {p, {mb, mp}, Ṽ_, {mb-LN:TtoNT, mp-LN:TtoNT}}, {t, {nt, nd}, Ṽ_, {nt-LN:TtoNT, nd-LN:TtoNT}}, {k, {ŋk, ŋɡ}, Ṽ_, {ŋk-LN:TtoNT, ŋɡ-LN:TtoNT}}, {j, ɲ, {Ṽ_, _Ṽ}, LN:j}, {i, ĩ, _{m, n, ŋ}, LN:V}, {ɨ, ɨ̃, _{m, n, ŋ}, LN:V}, {ɛ, ɛ̃, _{m, n, ŋ}, LN:V}, {a, ã, _{m, n, ŋ}, LN:V}, {ɔ, ɔ̃, _{m, n, ŋ}, LN:V}, {u, ũ, _{m, n, ŋ}, LN:V}}
/p t k/ pre-nasalizes to [mp, nt, ŋk]~[mb, nd, ŋɡ] after a nasal vowel
Nasalization of /j/ to [ɲ] before or after a nasal vowel
Oral vowels are nasalized before a root-final nasal consonant

We mostly adopt Drude's analysis and phonemic inventory for Awetí, supplementing processes from Monserrat as well. We differ from Drude's analysis in which we consider Awetí to have underlying voiceless obstruents (T) and nasal consonants (N), as opposed to the 3-way contrast between voiceless obstruents, nasal consonants, and underspecified root-final arciphonemes proposed by Drude. We also assume Awetí has contrastive oral (V) and nasal vowels (Ṽ) and do not consider neutral vowels to occur in Awetí.   We adopt 4 phonological processes: (1) leftward LDNH, triggered by root-final nasal vowels or nasal consonants, spreading leftward and nasalizing all oral vowels and approximants; voiceless obstruents {T} and /h/ are considered transparent to this process; (2) rightward LN, pre-nasalization of /p, t, ts, k/ to [mp, nt, ŋk, nts] ~ [nb, nd, ŋɡ] following a nasal vowel; (3) bidirectional LN, nasalization of the glides /w, j/ preceding or following a nasal vowel. /j/ contains two nasal allophones, which are in variation with each other: [j̃] ~ [ɲ]; (4) bidirectional LN, deletion of the nasal portion /m/ in the emphatic suffix {-mɛ} which triggers nasalization of the preceding root-final stops /p, t, k/ to [m, n, ŋ] as well as nasalization of the following /ɛ/ vowel in the suffix.

LDNH was coded as optional on the basis of the following assertion from Sabino 2016:44, citing Monserrat's (2002) chapter "Sobre a fonologia da língua Awetý": "Monserrat observa que as vogais em sílabas átonas que precedem uma sílaba tônica com vogal nasal, ou vogal mais consoante nasal, podem realizar-se ora orais, ora nasais, e que há, aparentemente, uma relação direta entre intensidade, alcance da nasalização, e rapidez da fala." Data is also presented here in support of this alternation.  A morphophonological alternation documented is that the suffix -mɛ nasalizes the final consonant of the preceding morpheme, and, in case that final consonant is /j/, also nasalize the vowel of /ɛ/ to [ɛ̃]. The /m/ then deletes (2020:20).

{{p, p}, {t, t}, {k, k}, {ts, ts}, {m, m}, {n, n}, {ŋ, ŋ}, {ɾ, ɾ}, {j, j}, {w, w}, {l, l}, {ʐ, ʐ}, {ɣ, ɣ}, {h, h}, {ʔ, ʔ}, {i, i}, {ɨ, ɨ}, {ɛ, ɛ}, {a, a}, {ɔ, ɔ}, {u, u}, {ĩ, ĩ}, {ɨ̃, ɨ̃}, {ɛ̃, ɛ̃}, {ã, ã}, {ɔ̃, ɔ̃}, {ũ, ũ}, {u, {u, o}, @, o-lowering}, {i, {i̯, j}, $*_, {i̯-vowel shortening, j-gliding}}, {u, {u̯, w}, $*_, {u̯-vowel shortening, w-gliding}}, {ɛ, j, $*_, gliding}, {t, tʃ, V_i, palatalization}, {p, {mp, mb}, Ṽ_, {mp-LN:TtoNT, mb-LN:TtoNT}}, {t, {nt, nd}, Ṽ_, {nt-LN:TtoNT, nd-LN:TtoNT}}, {k, {ŋk, ŋɡ}, Ṽ_, {ŋk-LN:TtoNT, ŋɡ-LN:TtoNT}}, {ts, {nts, nds, ndz}, Ṽ_, {nts-LN:TtoNT, nds-LN:TtoNT, ndz-LN:TtoNT}}, {i, ĩ, &, LDNH}, {ɨ, ɨ̃, &, LDNH}, {ɛ, ɛ̃, &, LDNH}, {a, ã, &, LDNH}, {ɔ, ɔ̃, &, LDNH}, {u, ũ, &, LDNH}, {w, w̃, &, LDNH}, {ɾ, ɾ̃, &, LDNH}, {j, j̃, &, LDNH}, {w, w̃, {Ṽ_, _Ṽ}, LN:wj}, {j, {j̃, ɲ}, {Ṽ_, _Ṽ}, {j̃-LN:wj, ɲ-LN:wj}}}
Root-final nasal vowel or nasal consonant spreads leftward nasalizing oral vowels and /ɾ, w, j/
/p, t, ts, k/ prenasalize to [mp~mb, nt~nd, nts~nds~ndz, ŋk~ŋɡ] after a nasal vowel
Nasalization of /w, j/ preceding or following a nasal vowel
Nasal portion of {-me} suffix nasalizes root-final {p, t, k} of preceding root and [ɛ] in suffix, then deletes
